Coresets for Vertical Federated Learning: Regularized Linear Regression and Kğ¾K-Means Clustering

Lingxiao Huang
Nanjing University
huanglingxiao1990@126.com
&Zhize Liâˆ—

Alphabetical order.
Abstract

Vertical federated learning (VFL), where data features are stored in multiple parties distributively, is an important area in machine learning. However, the communication complexity for VFL is typically very high. In this paper, we propose a unified framework by constructing coresets in a distributed fashion for communication-efficient VFL. We study two important learning tasks in the VFL setting: regularized linear regression and kğ‘˜k-means clustering, and apply our coreset framework to both problems. We theoretically show that using coresets can drastically alleviate the communication complexity, while nearly maintain the solution quality. Numerical experiments are conducted to corroborate our theoretical findings.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL)Â [54, 40, 44, 36, 68] is a learning framework where multiple clients/parties collaboratively train a machine learning model under the coordination of a central server without exposing their raw data (i.e., each partyâ€™s raw data is stored locally and not transferred). There are two large categories of FL, horizontal federated learning (HFL) and vertical federated learning (VFL), based on the distribution characteristics of the data. In HFL, different parties usually hold different datasets but all datasets share the same features; while in VFL, all parties use the same dataset but different parties hold different subsets of the features (see FigureÂ 1(a)).

Compared to HFL, VFLÂ [74, 50, 71] is generally harder and requires more communication: as a single party cannot observe the full features, it requires communication with other parties to compute the loss and the gradient of a single data. This will result in two potential problems: (i) it may require a huge amount of communication to jointly train the machine learning model when the dataset is large; and (ii) the procedure of VFL transfers the information of local data and may cause privacy leakage. Most of the VFL literature focus on the privacy issue, and designing secure training procedure for different machine learning models in the VFL settingÂ [28, 74, 72, 10]. However, the communication efficiency of the training procedure in VFL is somewhat underexplored. For unsupervised clustering problems, Ding etÂ al. [19] propose constant approximation schemes for kğ‘˜k-meansÂ clustering, and their communication complexity is linear in terms of the dataset size. For linear regression, although the communciaiton complexity can be improved to sublinear via sampling, such as SGD-type uniform sampling for the datasetÂ [50, 74], the final performance is not comparable to that using the whole dataset. Thus previous algorithms usually do not scale or perform well to the big data scenarios. 111In our numerical experiments (Section 6), we provide some results to justify this claim. This leads us to consider the following question:

How to train machine learning models using sublinear communication complexity in terms of the dataset size without sacrificing the performance in the vertical federated learning (VFL) setting?

In this paper, we try to answer this question, and our method is based on the notion of coresetÂ [27, 22, 23]. Roughly speaking, coreset can be viewed as a small data summary of the original dataset, and the machine learning model trained on the coreset performs similarly to the model trained using the full dataset. Therefore, as long as we can obtain a coreset in the VFL setting in a communication-efficient way, we can then run existing algorithms on the coreset instead of the full dataset.

Our contribution

We study the communication-efficient methods for vertical federated learning with an emphasis on scalability, and design a general paradigm through the lens of coreset. Concretely, we have the following key contributions:

  1. 1.

    We design a unified framework for coreset construction in the vertical federated learning setting (Section 3), which can help reduce the communication complexity (TheoremÂ 2.5).

  2. 2.

    We study the regularized linear regression (Definition 2.1) and kğ‘˜k-meansÂ (Definition 2.2) problems in the VFL setting, and apply our unified coreset construction framework to them. We show that we can get Îµğœ€{\varepsilon}-approximation for these two problems using only oâ€‹(n)ğ‘œğ‘›o(n) sublinear communications under mild conditions, where nğ‘›n is the size of the dataset (Section 4 and 5).

  3. 3.

    We conduct numerical experiments to validate our theoretical results. Our numerical experiments corroborate our findings that using coresets can drastically reduce the communication complexity, while maintaining the quality of the solution (Section 6). Moreover, compared to uniform sampling, applying our coresets can achieve a better solution with the same or smaller communication complexity.

1.1 More related works

Federated learning

Federated learning was introduced by McMahan etÂ al. [54], and received increasing attention in recent years. There exist many works studied in the horizontal federated learning (HFL) setting, such as algorithms with multiple local update stepsÂ [54, 17, 39, 25, 56, 77] . There are also many algorithms with communication compressionÂ [38, 55, 47, 45, 24, 46, 60, 21, 76, 61, 78] and algorithms with privacy preservingÂ [70, 30, 79, 64, 48].

Vertical federated learning

Due to the difficulties of VFL, people designed VFL algorithms for some particular machine learning models, including linear regressionÂ [50, 74], logistic regressionÂ [75, 73, 29], gradient boosting treesÂ [63, 11, 10], and kğ‘˜k-meansÂ [19]. For kğ‘˜k-means, Ding etÂ al. [19] proposed an algorithm that computes the global centers based on the product of local centers, which requires Oâ€‹(nâ€‹T)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘‡O(nT) communication complexity. For linear regression, Liu etÂ al. [50] and Yang etÂ al. [74] used uniform sampling to get unbiased gradient estimation and improved the communication efficiency, but the performance may not be good compared to that without sampling. Yang etÂ al. [73] also applied uniform sampling to quasi-Newton algorithm and improved communication complexity for logistic regression. People also studied other settings in VFL, e.g., how to align the data among different partiesÂ [62], how to adopt asynchronous trainingÂ [9, 26], and how to defend against attacks in VFLÂ [49, 53]. In this work, we aim to develop communication-efficient algorithms to handle large-scale VFL problems.

Coreset

Coresets have been applied to a large family of problems in machine learning and statistics, including clusteringÂ [22, 7, 31, 15, 16], regressionÂ [20, 43, 6, 13, 34, 12], low rank approximationÂ [14], and mixture modelÂ [52, 33]. Specifically, Chhaya etÂ al. [12] investigated coreset construction for regularized regression with different norms. Feldman and Langberg [22], Braverman etÂ al. [7] proposed an importance sampling framework for coreset construction for clustering (including kğ‘˜k-means). The coreset size for kğ‘˜k-meansÂ clustering has been improved by several following worksÂ [31, 15, 16] to O~â€‹(kâ€‹Îµâˆ’4)~ğ‘‚ğ‘˜superscriptğœ€4\tilde{O}(k{\varepsilon}^{-4}), and Cohen-Addad etÂ al. [16] proved a lower bound of size Î©â€‹(Îµâˆ’2â€‹k)Î©superscriptğœ€2ğ‘˜\Omega({\varepsilon}^{-2}k). Due to the mergable property of coresets, there have been studies on coreset construction in the distributed/horizontal settingÂ [2, 58, 1, 51]. To our knowledge, we are the first to consider coreset construction in VFL.

2 Problem Formulation/Model

In this section, we formally define our problems: coresets for vertical regularized linear regression and coresets for vertical kğ‘˜k-meansÂ clustering (ProblemÂ 1).

Vertical federated learning model.

We first introduce the model of vertical federated learning (VFL). Let ğ‘¿âŠ‚â„dğ‘¿superscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} be a dataset of size nğ‘›n that is vertically separated stored in Tğ‘‡T data parties (Tâ‰¥2ğ‘‡2T\geq 2). Note that âˆ‘jâˆˆ[T]dj=dsubscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘‘\sum_{j\in[T]}d_{j}=d. Additionally, if there is a label yiâˆˆâ„subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–â„y_{i}\in\mathbb{R} for each point ğ’™iâˆˆğ‘¿subscriptğ’™ğ‘–ğ‘¿{\bm{x}}_{i}\in{\bm{X}}, we assume the label vector ğ’šâˆˆâ„nğ’šsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›{\bm{y}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} is stored in Party Tğ‘‡T. The objective of vertical federated learning is to collaboratively solve certain training problems in the central server with a total communication complexity as small as possible.

Similar toÂ Ding etÂ al. [19, Figure 1], we only allow the communication between the central server and each of the Tğ‘‡T parties, and require the central server to hold the final solution. Note that the central server can also be replaced with any party in practice. For the communication complexity, we assume that transporting an integer/floating-point costs 1 unit, and consequently, transporting a dğ‘‘d-dimensional vector costs dğ‘‘d communication units. See FigureÂ 1(a) for an illustration.

Vertical regularized linear regression and vertical kğ‘˜k-meansÂ clustering.

In this paper, we consider the following two important machine learning problems in the VFL model.

Ding etÂ al. [19] proposed a similar vertical kğ‘˜k-meansÂ clustering problem and provided constant approximation schemes. To this end, we introduce a powerful data-reduction technique, called coresetsÂ [27, 22, 23].

Coresets for VRLR and VKMC.

Roughly speaking, a coreset is a small summary of the original dataset, that approximates the learning objective for every possible choice of learning parameters. We first define coresets for offline regularized linear regression and kğ‘˜k-meansÂ clustering as follows. As mentioned in SectionÂ 1.1, both problems have been well studied in the literatureÂ [22, 7, 12, 31, 15, 16].

Now we are ready to give the following main problem.

Problem 1 (Coreset construction for VRLR and VKMC).

Given a dataset ğ‘¿âŠ‚â„dğ‘¿superscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} (together with labels ğ’šâˆˆâ„nğ’šsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›{\bm{y}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}) in the VFL model and Îµâˆˆ(0,1)ğœ€01{\varepsilon}\in(0,1), our goal is to construct an Îµğœ€{\varepsilon}-coreset for regularized linear regression (or kğ‘˜k-meansÂ clustering) in the server, with as small communication complexity as possible. See FigureÂ 1(b) for an illustration.

Note that our coreset is a subset of indices which is slightly different from that in previous workÂ [27, 22, 23], whose coreset consists of weighted points. This is because we would like to reduce data transportation from parties to the server due to privacy considerations. Specifically, if the communication schemes for VRLR and VKMC do not need to make data transportation, then we can avoid data transportation by first applying our coreset construction scheme and then doing the communication schemes based on the coreset. Moreover, we have the following theorem that shows how coresets reduce the communication complexity in the VFL models, and the proof is in SectionÂ C.

Theorem 2.5 (Coresets reduce the communication complexity for VRLR and VKMC).

Given Îµâˆˆ(0,1)ğœ€01{\varepsilon}\in(0,1), suppose there exist

    a communication scheme Ağ´A that given a (weighted) dataset ğ‘¿âŠ‚â„dğ‘¿superscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} together with labels ğ’šâˆˆâ„nğ’šsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›{\bm{y}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} in the VFL model, computes an Î±ğ›¼\alpha-approximate solution (Î±â‰¥1ğ›¼1\alpha\geq 1) for VRLR (or VKMC) in the server with a communication complexity Î›â€‹(n)Î›ğ‘›\Lambda(n);

Then there exists a communication scheme that given a (weighted) dataset ğ—âŠ‚â„dğ—superscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} together with labels ğ²âˆˆâ„nğ²superscriptâ„ğ‘›{\bm{y}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} in the VFL model, computes an (1+3â€‹Îµ)â€‹Î±13ğœ€ğ›¼(1+3{\varepsilon})\alpha-approximate solution (Î±â‰¥1ğ›¼1\alpha\geq 1) for VRLR (or VKMC respectively) in the server with a communication complexity Î›0+2â€‹mâ€‹T+Î›â€‹(m)subscriptÎ›02ğ‘šğ‘‡Î›ğ‘š\Lambda_{0}+2mT+\Lambda(m).

3 A Unified Scheme for VFL Coresets via Importance Sampling

In this section, we propose a unified communication scheme (AlgorithmÂ 1) that will be used as a meta-algorithm for solving ProblemÂ 1.     Let Î¶=maxiâˆˆ[n]â¡supğ‘ªâˆˆğ’ğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—iCâ€‹(ğ‘¿,ğ‘ª)ğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—Câ€‹(ğ‘¿,ğ‘ª)/âˆ‘jâˆˆ[T]gi(j)ğœsubscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptsupremumğ‘ªğ’subscriptsuperscriptğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—ğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘¿ğ‘ªsuperscriptğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—ğ¶ğ‘¿ğ‘ªsubscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘—\zeta=\max\limits_{i\in[n]}\nicefrac{{\sup\limits_{{\bm{C}}\in{\mathcal{C}}}\frac{\mathsf{cost}^{C}_{i}({\bm{X}},{\bm{C}})}{\mathsf{cost}^{C}({\bm{X}},{\bm{C}})}}}{{\sum_{j\in[T]}g_{i}^{(j)}}} and m=Oâ€‹(Îµâˆ’2â€‹Î¶â€‹ğ’¢â€‹(dâ€‹kâ€‹logâ¡(Î¶â€‹ğ’¢)+logâ¡(1/Î´)))ğ‘šğ‘‚superscriptğœ€2ğœğ’¢ğ‘‘ğ‘˜ğœğ’¢1ğ›¿m=O\left({\varepsilon}^{-2}\zeta{\mathcal{G}}(dk\log(\zeta{\mathcal{G}})+\log(1/\delta))\right). The proof can be found in AppendixÂ D. The main idea is to show that AlgorithmÂ 1 simulates a well-known importance sampling framework for offline coreset construction byÂ [22, 7]. The term supğœ½âˆˆâ„dğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—iRâ€‹(ğ‘¿,ğœ½)ğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—Râ€‹(ğ‘¿,ğœ½)subscriptsupremumğœ½superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—ğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘¿ğœ½superscriptğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—ğ‘…ğ‘¿ğœ½\sup_{{\bm{\theta}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\frac{\mathsf{cost}^{R}_{i}({\bm{X}},{\bm{\theta}})}{\mathsf{cost}^{R}({\bm{X}},{\bm{\theta}})} (or supğ‘ªâˆˆğ’ğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—iCâ€‹(ğ‘¿,ğ‘ª)ğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—Câ€‹(ğ‘¿,ğ‘ª)subscriptsupremumğ‘ªğ’subscriptsuperscriptğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—ğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘¿ğ‘ªsuperscriptğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—ğ¶ğ‘¿ğ‘ª\sup_{{\bm{C}}\in{\mathcal{C}}}\frac{\mathsf{cost}^{C}_{i}({\bm{X}},{\bm{C}})}{\mathsf{cost}^{C}({\bm{X}},{\bm{C}})}) is called the sensitivity of point ğ’™isubscriptğ’™ğ‘–{\bm{x}}_{i} for VRLR (or VKMC) that represents the maximum contribution of ğ’™isubscriptğ’™ğ‘–{\bm{x}}_{i} over all possible parameters. AlgorithmÂ 1 aims to use âˆ‘jâˆˆ[T]gi(j)subscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘—\sum_{j\in[T]}g_{i}^{(j)} to estimate the sensitivity of ğ’™isubscriptğ’™ğ‘–{\bm{x}}_{i}, and hence, Î¶ğœ\zeta represents the maximum sensitivity gap over all points. The performance of AlgorithmÂ 1 mainly depends on the quality of these estimations âˆ‘jâˆˆ[T]gi(j)subscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘—\sum_{j\in[T]}g_{i}^{(j)}. As both Î¶ğœ\zeta and the total sum ğ’¢=âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n],jâˆˆ[T]gi(j)ğ’¢subscriptformulae-sequenceğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘—{\mathcal{G}}=\sum_{i\in[n],j\in[T]}g_{i}^{(j)} become smaller, the required size mğ‘šm becomes smaller. Specifically, if both Î¶ğœ\zeta and ğ’¢ğ’¢{\mathcal{G}} only depends on parameters k,d,Tğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘‡k,d,T, the coreset size mğ‘šm is independent of nğ‘›n as expected. Combining with TheoremÂ 2.5, we can heavily reduce the communication complexity for VRLR or VKMC.

Privacy issue.

We consider the privacy of the proposed scheme from two aspects: coreset construction and model training. As for the coreset construction part (Algorithm 1), the privacy leakage comes from the "sensitivity score" gi(j)superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘—g_{i}^{(j)} of the data points in different parties. To tackle this problem, we can use secure aggregation [5] to transport the sum gi=âˆ‘j=1Tgi(j)subscriptğ‘”ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘—g_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{T}g_{i}^{(j)} to the server without revealing the exact values of gi(j)superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘—g_{i}^{(j)}s (Line 7 of AlgorithmÂ 1). The server only knows (S,w)ğ‘†ğ‘¤(S,w) and ğ’¢(j)superscriptğ’¢ğ‘—{\mathcal{G}}^{(j)}s. For the model training part, we can apply the secure VFL algorithms if existed, e.g., using homomorphic encryption on SAGA for regression (it is an extension from SGD to SAGA [28]).

Note that the VFL communication model in SectionÂ 2 is assumed to be semi-honest. Suppose some party jğ‘—j is malicious, then it can report a large enough ğ’¢(j)superscriptğ’¢ğ‘—{\mathcal{G}}^{(j)} (Line 2 of AlgorithmÂ 1) such that the server sets the number of samples ajâ‰ˆmsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘ša_{j}\approx m in party jğ‘—j (Line 4 of AlgorithmÂ 1). Consequently, party jğ‘—j can sample a large multi-set S(j)superscriptğ‘†ğ‘—S^{(j)} which heavily affects the resulting set Sğ‘†S. For instance, by reporting S(j)superscriptğ‘†ğ‘—S^{(j)} of uniform samples, party jğ‘—j can make Sğ‘†S close to uniform sampling and loss the theoretical guarantees in TheoremÂ 3.1.

4 Coreset Construction for VRLR

In this section, we discuss the coreset construction for VRLR. We first show that it is generally hard to construct a strong coreset for VRLR. Then, we show how to communication-efficiently construct coresets for VRLR under mild assumption. All missing proofs can be found in SectionÂ E.

With slightly abuse of notation, we denote ğ‘¿âˆˆâ„nÃ—d,ğ‘¿(j)âˆˆâ„nÃ—djformulae-sequenceğ‘¿superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘¿ğ‘—superscriptâ„ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—{\bm{X}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d},{\bm{X}}^{(j)}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d_{j}} to be the data matrix of whole data and the data matrix stored on party jğ‘—j respectively. Since there are labels ğ’šğ’š{\bm{y}} stored on party Tğ‘‡T, ğ‘¿(T)superscriptğ‘¿ğ‘‡{\bm{X}}^{(T)} has dimension nÃ—(dT+1)ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘‡1n\times(d_{T}+1).

Communication complexity lower bound for VRLR

We first show that it is hard to compute the coreset for VRLR by proving an Î©â€‹(n)Î©ğ‘›\Omega(n) deterministic communication complexity lower bound.

Theorem 4.1 (Communication complexity of coreset construction for VRLR).

Let Tâ‰¥2ğ‘‡2T\geq 2. Given constant Îµâˆˆ(0,1)ğœ€01{\varepsilon}\in(0,1), any deterministic communication scheme that constructs an Îµğœ€{\varepsilon}-coreset for VRLR requires a communication complexity Î©â€‹(n)Î©ğ‘›\Omega(n).

The communication complexity lower bound for linear regression has also been considered in the HFL settingÂ [67], e.g., Vempala etÂ al. [67] also gets a deterministic communication complexity lower bound. Theorem 4.1 shows that linear regression in the VFL setting is â€œhardâ€ and thus we may need to add data assumptions to get theoretical guarantees for coreset construction.

Communication-efficient coreset construction for VRLR

Now we show that under mild condition, we can construct a strong coreset for VRLR using oâ€‹(n)ğ‘œğ‘›o(n) number of communication. Specifically, we assume the data ğ‘¿ğ‘¿{\bm{X}} satisfies the following assumption, which will be justified in the appendix.

Assumption 4.1.

Let ğ”(j)âˆˆâ„nÃ—djâ€²superscriptğ”ğ‘—superscriptâ„ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â€²ğ‘—{\bm{U}}^{(j)}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d^{\prime}_{j}} denote the orthonormal basis of the column space of ğ—(j)superscriptğ—ğ‘—{\bm{X}}^{(j)} stored on party jğ‘—j (ğ”(T)superscriptğ”ğ‘‡{\bm{U}}^{(T)} denotes the orthonormal basis of [ğ—(T),y]superscriptğ—ğ‘‡ğ‘¦[{\bm{X}}^{(T)},y]), and then the matrix ğ”=[ğ”(1),ğ”(2),â€¦,ğ”(T)]ğ”superscriptğ”1superscriptğ”2â€¦superscriptğ”ğ‘‡{\bm{U}}=[{\bm{U}}^{(1)},{\bm{U}}^{(2)},\dots,{\bm{U}}^{(T)}] has smallest singular value Ïƒminâ€‹(ğ”)â‰¥Î³>0subscriptğœğ”ğ›¾0\sigma_{\min}({\bm{U}})\geq\gamma>0.

Intuitively, Î³âˆˆ(0,1]ğ›¾01\gamma\in(0,1] represents the degree of orthonormal among data in different parties. Now we introduce our coreset construction algorithm for VRLR (Algorithm 2). To do this, we apply the DIS procedure (Algorithm 1).

Theorem 4.2 (Coresets for VRLR).

For a given dataset ğ—âŠ‚â„dğ—superscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} satisfying AssumptionÂ 4.1, number of parties Tâ‰¥1ğ‘‡1T\geq 1 and constants Îµ,Î´âˆˆ(0,1)ğœ€ğ›¿01{\varepsilon},\delta\in(0,1), with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta, Algorithm 2 constructs an Îµğœ€{\varepsilon}-coreset for VRLR of size m=Oâ€‹(Îµâˆ’2â€‹Î³âˆ’2â€‹dâ€‹(d2â€‹logâ¡Î³âˆ’2â€‹d+logâ¡1/Î´))ğ‘šğ‘‚superscriptğœ€2superscriptğ›¾2ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘‘2superscriptğ›¾2ğ‘‘1ğ›¿m=O({\varepsilon}^{-2}\gamma^{-2}d(d^{2}\log{\gamma^{-2}d}+\log{1/\delta})), and uses communication complexity Oâ€‹(mâ€‹T)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğ‘‡O(mT).

Note that the coreset size and the total communication are all independent on nğ‘›n, and thus when combined with Theorem 2.5, using coreset construction can reduce the communication complexity for VRLR. When Assumption 4.1 is not satisfied, Algorithm 4.2 is not guaranteed to return a strong coreset. However, as shown in the following remark, it will return another kind of coreset called robust coreset Â [22, 32, 69], which allows a small portion of data to be treated as outliers and excluded both in Sğ‘†S and ğ‘¿ğ‘¿{\bm{X}} when evaluating the quality of Sğ‘†S. The outliers represent a small percentage of data with unbounded sensitivity gap. More details can be found in the TheoremÂ G.3.

5 Coreset Construction for VKMC

In this section, we discuss the coreset construction for VKMC. Similar to VRLR, we first show it generally requires Î©â€‹(n)Î©ğ‘›\Omega(n) communication complexity to construct a coreset for VKMC, and then we show that it is possible to vastly reduce the communication complexity (AlgorithmÂ 3) under mild data assumption. All missing proofs can be found in SectionÂ F.

Communication complexity lower bound for VKMC.

We first present an Î©â€‹(n)Î©ğ‘›\Omega(n) communication complexity lower bound for constructing an Îµğœ€{\varepsilon}-coreset for VKMC in the following theorem.

Theorem 5.1 (Communication complexity of coreset construction for VKMC).

Let dâ‰¥Tâ‰¥2ğ‘‘ğ‘‡2d\geq T\geq 2. Given a constant Îµâˆˆ(0,1)ğœ€01{\varepsilon}\in(0,1) and an integer kâ‰¥3ğ‘˜3k\geq 3, any randomized communication scheme that constructs an Îµğœ€{\varepsilon}-coreset for VKMC with probability 0.99 requires a communication complexity Î©â€‹(n)Î©ğ‘›\Omega(n).

Different from VRLR, we have a randomized communication complexity lower bound for VKMC. Similarly, we also need to introduce certain data assumptions to get theoretical guarantees for coreset construction due to this hardness result.

Communication-efficient coreset construction for VKMC

Now we show how to communication-efficiently construct coresets for VKMC under mild condition. Specifically, we assume that the data satisfies the following assumption, which will be justified in the appendix.

Assumption 5.1.

There exists Ï„â‰¥1ğœ1\tau\geq 1 and some party tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T] such that â€–ğ±iâˆ’ğ±jâ€–2â‰¤Ï„â€‹â€–ğ±i(t)âˆ’ğ±j(t)â€–2superscriptnormsubscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘—2ğœsuperscriptnormsubscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘¡ğ‘—2\left\|{\bm{x}}_{i}-{\bm{x}}_{j}\right\|^{2}\leq\tau\left\|{\bm{x}}^{(t)}_{i}-{\bm{x}}^{(t)}_{j}\right\|^{2} for any i,jâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘›i,j\in[n].

This assumption says that, there is a party that is â€œimportantâ€, and any two data points which can be differentiated can also be differentiated on that party to some extent. Specifically, as Ï„ğœ\tau is more close to 1, Assumption 5.1 implies that there exists a party tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T] whose local pairwise distances â€–xi(t)âˆ’xj(t)â€–normsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—ğ‘¡\|x_{i}^{(t)}-x_{j}^{(t)}\|s are close to the corresponding global pairwise distances â€–xiâˆ’xjâ€–normsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—\|x_{i}-x_{j}\|s. Then we introduce our coreset construction algorithm for VKMC (AlgorithmÂ 3). For the input, note that there exist several constant approximation algorithms for kğ‘˜k-meansÂ  [41, 66]. The widely used kğ‘˜k-means++ algorithm [66] provides an Oâ€‹(lnâ¡k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(\ln{k})-approximation and performs well in practice. Similar to AlgorithmÂ 2 for VRLR, AlgorithmÂ 3 also applies AlgorithmÂ 1 after computing gi(j)superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘—g_{i}^{(j)} locally. The key is to construct local sensitivities gi(j)superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘—g_{i}^{(j)} to upper bound both Î¶ğœ\zeta and ğ’¢ğ’¢{\mathcal{G}} in TheoremÂ 3.1. The derivation of the local sensitivities gi(j)superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘—g_{i}^{(j)} defined in Line 10 is partly inspired by [65], which upper bounds the total sensitivity of a point set in clustering problems by projecting points onto an optimal solution. Intuitively, if some party tğ‘¡t satisfies AssumptionÂ 5.1, a constant factor approximate solution computed locally in party tğ‘¡t can also induce a global one. Then by projecting points onto this global constant approximation, we can prove that gi(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘¡g_{i}^{(t)} (scaled by some constant factor) is an upper bound of the global sensitivity of ğ’™isubscriptğ’™ğ‘–{\bm{x}}_{i} for any iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]. Though unaware of which party satisfies AssumptionÂ 5.1, it suffices to sum up gi(j)superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘—g_{i}^{(j)} over jâˆˆ[T]ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘‡j\in[T], only costing an additional Tğ‘‡T in ğ’¢ğ’¢{\mathcal{G}}. Finally, we can upper bound Î¶ğœ\zeta by Oâ€‹(Ï„)ğ‘‚ğœO(\tau) and ğ’¢ğ’¢{\mathcal{G}} by Oâ€‹(kâ€‹T)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘‡O(kT) respectively. The main theorem is as follows.

Theorem 5.2 (Coresets for VKMC).

For a given dataset ğ—âŠ‚â„dğ—superscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} satisfying AssumptionÂ 5.1, an Î±ğ›¼\alpha-approximation algorithm for kğ‘˜k-meansÂ with Î±=Oâ€‹(1)ğ›¼ğ‘‚1\alpha=O(1), integers kâ‰¥1ğ‘˜1k\geq 1, Tâ‰¥1ğ‘‡1T\geq 1 and constants Îµ,Î´âˆˆ(0,1)ğœ€ğ›¿01{\varepsilon},\delta\in(0,1), with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta, Algorithm 3 constructs an Îµğœ€{\varepsilon}-coreset for VKMC of size m=Oâ€‹(Îµâˆ’2â€‹Î±â€‹Ï„â€‹kâ€‹Tâ€‹(dâ€‹kâ€‹logâ¡(Î±â€‹Ï„â€‹kâ€‹T)+logâ¡1/Î´))ğ‘šğ‘‚superscriptğœ€2ğ›¼ğœğ‘˜ğ‘‡ğ‘‘ğ‘˜ğ›¼ğœğ‘˜ğ‘‡1ğ›¿m=O({\varepsilon}^{-2}\alpha\tau kT(dk\log{(\alpha\tau kT)}+\log{1/\delta})), and uses communication complexity Oâ€‹(mâ€‹T)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğ‘‡O(mT).

Again, note that both the coreset size and communication complexity are independent of nğ‘›n. Thus, using Algorithm 3 together with other baseline algorithms can drastically reduce the communication complexity. Similar to VRLR, we have the following remark when the data assumption (Assumption 5.1) is not satisfied. More details can be found in the Theorem G.4.

Remark 5.3 (Robust coreset for VKMC).

Given a dataset ğ—âŠ‚â„dğ—superscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}, an integer kâ‰¥1ğ‘˜1k\geq 1, Îµâˆˆ(0,1)ğœ€01{\varepsilon}\in(0,1) and Î²âˆˆ[0,1)ğ›½01\beta\in[0,1), a subset SâŠ†[n]ğ‘†delimited-[]ğ‘›S\subseteq[n] together with a weight function w:Sâ†’â„â‰¥0:ğ‘¤â†’ğ‘†subscriptâ„absent0w:S\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} is called a (Î²,Îµ)ğ›½ğœ€(\beta,{\varepsilon})-robust coreset for offline kğ‘˜k-meansÂ clustering if for any ğ‚âŠ‚â„dğ‚superscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\bm{C}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}, there exists a subset Oğ‚âŠ†[n]subscriptğ‘‚ğ‚delimited-[]ğ‘›O_{{\bm{C}}}\subseteq[n] such that |Oğ‚|/nâ‰¤Î²subscriptğ‘‚ğ‚ğ‘›ğ›½|O_{{\bm{C}}}|/n\leq\beta, |Sâˆ©Oğ‚|/|S|â‰¤Î²ğ‘†subscriptğ‘‚ğ‚ğ‘†ğ›½|S\cap O_{{\bm{C}}}|/|S|\leq\beta and

ğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—Câ€‹(S\Oğ‘ª,ğ‘ª)âˆˆğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—Câ€‹(ğ‘¿\Oğ‘ª,ğ‘ª)Â±Îµâ‹…ğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—Câ€‹(ğ‘¿,ğ‘ª).superscriptğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—ğ¶\ğ‘†subscriptğ‘‚ğ‘ªğ‘ªplus-or-minussuperscriptğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—ğ¶\ğ‘¿subscriptğ‘‚ğ‘ªğ‘ªâ‹…ğœ€superscriptğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—ğ¶ğ‘¿ğ‘ª\mathsf{cost}^{C}(S\backslash O_{{\bm{C}}},{\bm{C}})\in\mathsf{cost}^{C}({\bm{X}}\backslash O_{{\bm{C}}},{\bm{C}})\pm{\varepsilon}\cdot\mathsf{cost}^{C}({\bm{X}},{\bm{C}}).

If Assumption 5.1 is not satisfied, for m=Oâ€‹((Îµâ€‹Î²)âˆ’2â€‹k5â€‹d)ğ‘šğ‘‚superscriptğœ€ğ›½2superscriptğ‘˜5ğ‘‘m=O(({\varepsilon}\beta)^{-2}k^{5}d) Algorithm 3 will return a (Î²,Îµ)ğ›½ğœ€(\beta,{\varepsilon})-robust coreset for VKMC with communication complexity Oâ€‹(mâ€‹T)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğ‘‡O(mT).

6 Numerical Experiments

In this section, we present the numerical experiments, which corroborate our theoretical results. We conduct experiments on a single system that simulates the distributed settings.222The codes are available at https://github.com/haoyuzhao123/coreset-vfl-codes.

Empirical setup.

We conduct experiments on the YearPredictionMSD datasetÂ [4] for both VRLR and VKMC. YearPredictionMSD dataset has 515345 data, and each data contains 90 features and a corresponding label. We assume there are T=3ğ‘‡3T=3 parties and each party stories 30 distinct features. For VRLR, we split the data into a training set with size 463715 and a testing set with size 51630. We consider ridge regression in VRLR by letting Râ€‹(ğœ½)=Î»â€‹â€–ğœ½â€–2ğ‘…ğœ½ğœ†superscriptnormğœ½2R({\bm{\theta}})=\lambda\left\|{\bm{\theta}}\right\|^{2} for Î»=0.1â€‹nğœ†0.1ğ‘›\lambda=0.1n where nğ‘›n is the dataset size. For VKMC, there is only one training set with size 515345 and without labels. We choose k=10ğ‘˜10k=10 (10 centers) and we normalize each feature with mean 0 and standard deviation 1 for VKMC.

For VRLR, we consider two baselines: 1) Central as the procedure that transfers all data to the central server and solves the problem using scikit-learn packageÂ [57]; 2) SAGA as using [18]â€™s algorithm to optimize in a VFL fashion. For VKMC, we also consider two baselines: 1) Kmeans++ as the procedure that transfers all data to the central server and clusters using Kmeans++Â [66]; 2) DistDim by [19].

For each baseline, we compare our coreset algorithm with uniform sampling. We use C-X to denote coreset sampling followed by algorithm X and U-X for uniform sampling followed by algorithm X, e.g. C-DistDim means that we apply coreset construction and then use DistDim algorithm. We compare C-X and U-X with different sizes, and each experiment is repeated 20 times.

Empirical results.

Figure 2 shows our results for VRLR and Figure 3 shows our results for VKMC. Table 1 summarize the results. For VRLR, since it is a supervised learning problem, we report the testing loss; for VKMC, it is an unsupervised learning task and the cost refers to the training loss on the full training data.

Coreset sampling performs close to the baseline with less communication.

From the results, we find that using our coreset can achieve a similar loss compared to the baseline, while the communication complexity is reduced drastically. Specifically by TableÂ 1, our coreset algorithm C-Central can use less than 0.4% of training data (2000/463715) and achieve a 95.01/90.45â‰ˆ1.0595.0190.451.0595.01/90.45\approx 1.05-approximate solution for VRLR compared to the baseline Central. Observe that a larger coreset size leads to a smaller cost and a larger communication complexity. From Figures 2 and 3 (left), using coresets can reduce 50-100x communication complexity compared with the original baselines.

Coreset performs better than uniform sampling under the same communication.

From FiguresÂ 2 and 3 (right), we observe that our coresets always achieve a better solution than uniform sampling under the same sample size. Table 1 also reflects this trend. Under the same sample size, the communication complexity by uniform sampling is slightly lower than that of coreset, since there is no need to transfer weights in uniform sampling. Thus, we also compare the performance of our coresets and uniform sampling under the same communication complexity. From FiguresÂ 2 and 3 (left), we find that for different baselines, our coreset algorithms still achieve better testing loss/training cost while using fewer or the same communication, compared to uniform sampling.

Coreset and uniform sampling may also make the problem feasible.

It is also interesting to observe that SAGA will not converge (or very slowly) on the original VRLR problem (TableÂ 1), possibly because of the large dataset and the ill-conditioned optimization problem. However, by applying the coreset/uniform sampling, SAGA works for VRLR. This also indicates the effectiveness of our framework and the importance to reduce the dependency on nğ‘›n (the dataset size).

7 Conclusion and Future Directions

In this paper, we first consider coreset construction in the vertical federated learning setting. We propose a unified coreset framework for communication-efficient VFL, and apply the framework to two important learning tasks: regularized linear regression and kğ‘˜k-means clustering. We verify the efficiency of our coreset algorithms both theoretically and empirically, which can drastically alleviate the communication complexity while still maintaining the solution quality.

Our work initializes the topic of introducing coresets to VFL, which leaves several future directions. Firstly, our VFL coreset size is still larger than that of offline coresets for both VRLR and VKMC, even under certain data assumptions. One direction is to further improve the coreset size. Another interesting direction is to extend coreset construction to other learning tasks in the VFL setting, e.g., logistic regression or gradient boosting trees.

Appendix

Appendix A Additional Experiments

In this section, we present some additional experiments. This section is organized as follow: in Section A.1, we conduct experiments using different number of parties (as opposed to three parties in Section 6); in Section A.2, we test our methods using other regularizer for VRLR, e.g., Lasso; in Section A.3, we test our methods in VKMC with different number of centers; and finally in Section A.4, we conduct experiments on another dataset (KC House DatasetÂ [35]).

A.1 Different number of parties

In this section, we test our algorithms using different number of parties. We choose to use five parties (T=5ğ‘‡5T=5) in this section instead of three parties in Section 6.

Empirical setup

Most of the experimental setups are the same as those in Section 6, except that now we use 5 parties instead of 3 parties. There are 90 dimensions for a single data in YearPredictionMSD dataset, and we let each party hold 18 dimensions. Besides, changing the number of parties does not affect the performance of U-Central and U-SAGA (but the number of communication will change due to different number of parties), and we reuse the results from Section 6 and recalculate the number of communications.

Empirical results

Figure 4 and 5 summarize our results for VRLR and VKMC respectively. Note that all the observations in Section 6 hold for 5 parties.

A.2 Different regularizer for VRLR

In this part, we consider using different regularizers in VRLR.

Empirical setup

We consider three different regression problems: plain linear regression, Lasso regression, and elastic nets. In Section 6, we consider the Ridge regression (Râ€‹(ğœ½)=0.1â€‹nâ€‹â€–ğœ½â€–22ğ‘…ğœ½0.1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptnormğœ½22R({\bm{\theta}})=0.1n\left\|{\bm{\theta}}\right\|_{2}^{2} where nğ‘›n is the dataset size), and in this part, linear regression denotes the optimization problem where Râ€‹(ğœ½)=0ğ‘…ğœ½0R({\bm{\theta}})=0, Lasso regression denotes the problem where Râ€‹(ğœ½)=2â€‹nâ€‹â€–ğœ½â€–1ğ‘…ğœ½2ğ‘›subscriptnormğœ½1R({\bm{\theta}})=2n\left\|{\bm{\theta}}\right\|_{1}, and elastic net denotes the problem where Râ€‹(ğœ½)=2â€‹nâ€‹â€–ğœ½â€–1+nâ€‹â€–ğœ½â€–22ğ‘…ğœ½2ğ‘›subscriptnormğœ½1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptnormğœ½22R({\bm{\theta}})=2n\left\|{\bm{\theta}}\right\|_{1}+n\left\|{\bm{\theta}}\right\|_{2}^{2}. All the experiments setup remains the same as Section 6, except the for Lasso regression and elastic nets, there is no SAGA solver and we only compare C-Central and U-Central with Central.

Empirical results

We plot the training loss instead of the testing loss since we are comparing different objective functions. Figure 6, 7, and 8 show the empirical results in this part. Note that all the observations in Section 6 also hold: (1) coreset sampling and uniform sampling can drastically reduce the communication complexity where nearly maintain the solution performance, and (2) coreset performs better than uniform sampling under the same number of communication.

A.3 Different number of centers for VKMC

In this section we test our methods on VKMC using different number of centers.

Empirical setup

The experimental setup in this part is the same as the setup in Section 6 for VKMC, except that we are using 5 centers instead of 10 centers.

Empirical results

Figure 9 summarizes the result. All the observations in Section 6 also hold.

A.4 Experiments on other datasets

In this section, we present the experiment results on another dataset. We choose the KC House DatasetÂ [35] for both VRLR and VKMC.

Empirical setup

Our experiment setup is nearly the same as the setup in Section 6. However, there are a few differences: (1) the dataset we use is KC House DatasetÂ [35], which contains 21613 data points and each datapoint constains 18 features and a label; (2) we conduct the experiment using only two parties because the limited number of features, we put the first nine features on the first party and the remaining on the second; and (3), we do not consider regularizer for VRLR (plain linear regression). Also note that similar to Section 6, we normalize each feature to have standard deviation 1 during the clustering task.

Empirical results

For VRLR, we plot the training loss instead of the testing loss, since the dataset is not so large and coreset does not have theoretical guarantee for generalization error. Figure 10 and 11 summarize our results for VRLR and VKMC respectively. From the results, we still find that our coreset construction method can outperform uniform sampling, and both of them can drastically reduce the communication complexity compared with the original baselines.

Note that in Figure 10, C-SAGA and U-SAGA performs much worse than the baseline Central. However, C-Central can perform much better and has similar performance as Central, and this phenomenon may attribute to the fact that this problem is hard to solve by SAGA algorithm, and using other second-order methodsÂ [73] may help. Also note that when the size is small (100 and 200), U-Central may produce â€œridiculousâ€ solutions and the cost blows up.

Appendix B Justification of Data Assumptions

In this section, we justify our data assumptions in Section 4 (Assumption 4.1) and Section 5 (Assumption 5.1). We show that in the smoothed analysis regime, Assumption 4.1 and 5.1 are easy to satisfy with some standard assumptions. In Section B.1, we show the results related to Assumption 4.1, and in Section B.2, we justify Assumption 5.1.

B.1 Justification of Assumption 4.1

In this section, we interpret and justify Assumption 4.1. First, we recall Assumption 4.1.

See 4.1

Assumption 4.1 requires that the subspace generated by any party cannot be included in the subspace generated by all other parties. However, it it not sure what standard assumptions can lead to Assumption 4.1. B.2 Justification of Assumption 5.1

In this section, we justify Assumption 5.1. We first recall the assumption.

See 5.1

Roughly speaking, this assumption requires there is a party that is â€œimportantâ€, and any two data points which can be differentiated can also be differentiated on that party to some extent. In reality, this assumption should be approximately satisfied since different features should be â€œcorrelatedâ€.

Next, similar to the justification of Assumption 4.1, we use smoothed analysis framework to show that for dataset ğ‘¿ğ‘¿{\bm{X}} under certain conditions, by perturbing the dataset for a little bit, Assumption 5.1 will be satisfied with high probability. Formally, we have the following theorem.

Theorem B.2.

For any dataset where each data point â€–ğ±iâ€–22â‰¤Bsuperscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğ±ğ‘–22ğµ\left\|{\bm{x}}_{i}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq B for all ğ±iâˆˆğ—subscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ—{\bm{x}}_{i}\in{\bm{X}} and maxjâˆˆ[T]â¡djâ‰¥Î©â€‹(log2â¡n)subscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—Î©superscript2ğ‘›\max_{j\in[T]}d_{j}\geq\Omega(\log^{2}n). Lemma E.2.

F.1 Communication lower bound for VKMC coreset construction

The proof is via a reduction from a set-disjointness (DISJ) problem to the problem of coreset construction for VKMC.

DISJ problem.

Appendix G Robust Coresets for VRLR and VKMC

In this section, we prove that even if the data assumptionsÂ 4.1 andÂ 5.1 fail to hold, AlgorithmsÂ 2 andÂ 3 still provide robust coresets for VRLR (TheoremÂ G.3) and VKMC (TheoremÂ G.4) in the flavor of approximating with outliers.

G.1 Robust coreset

In this section, we introduce a general definition of robust coreset. Let Î²âˆˆ[0,1)ğ›½01\beta\in[0,1), and Îµâˆˆ(0,1)ğœ€01{\varepsilon}\in(0,1).
